content: I tested your issue in my Local Folders. The simplest way to move the sub-folder *04 from *03 back to its ancient position is a drag & drop action on the Local Folders name (see image). After the drop on Local Folders the folder *04 will automatically be inserted between folders *03 and *05. It works for me whether I do this drag & drop operation in All Folders or Unified Folders view. One can also try to drag folder *03 directly to its ancient position but this is a very tedious operation with a high failure rate.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Copy it into your Local Folders with TB closed > delete the .mbox extension > restart TB > look under Local Folders.

To find Local Folders, open your TB profile:

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

Local Folders should be in profile folder\Mail\Local Folders.
creator: siffemoz

content: In the POP account, assuming it is still there, look for a file named msgfilterrules.dat from within windows file explorer. This is a simple text file. If very careful, you can edit the file in Notepad if you know what changes are needed and then copy to the IMAP account (with thunderbird not running) and the restart thunderbird. It's a bit tricky, but doable and worth the effort if there are many filters. Good luck to you.
creator: davidsk

content: - click the 'new message' button - now, if the menu bar is not visible, click the alt key to display it - now, click view>toolbars and tick the 'composition toolbar'
